question: Question_01_(f)
statement:
\textbf{Sequences and Series: Short Answer Problems - Determine whether
the following sequences and series converge (full marks for correct
answer with justification; work must be shown for partial marks)}

Determine all \emph{x} such that the series
$\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{n(x+2)^n}{3^n(n+5)}$ converges.
sols:
Using the ratio test, we have that

\begin{align*}
\lim_{n \to \infty} \big| \frac{a_{n+1}}{a_{n}} \big| &= \lim_{n \to \infty}\big| a_{n+1}a_{n}^{-1} \big|\\
&= \lim_{n \to \infty}\big| \frac{(n+1)(x+2)^{n+1}}{3^{n+1}((n+1)+5)} \cdot \frac{3^n(n+5)}{n(x+2)^n}\big| \\
&= \lim_{n \to \infty}\big| \frac{(n+1)(x+2)}{3(n+6)} \cdot \frac{(n+5)}{n}\big| \\
&= \frac{|x+2|}{3} \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{(n+1)(n+5)}{n(n+6)} \\
&= \frac{|x+2|}{3} \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n^2(1+\tfrac{1}{n})(1+\tfrac{5}{n})}{n^2(1+\tfrac{6}{n})} \\
&= \frac{|x+2|}{3} \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{(1+\tfrac{1}{n})(1+\tfrac{5}{n})}{1+\tfrac{6}{n}} \\
&= \frac{|x+2|}{3} \cdot (1) \\
&= \frac{|x+2|}{3}\end{align*}

Now the ratio test tells us that our original series converges when
$\displaystyle |x+2|/3 < 1$.

This occurs when $\displaystyle |x+2|< 3$ so whenever the distance from
2 is bounded above by 3.

This occurs when $\displaystyle -5 < x < 1$. Another way to see this is
to note that $\displaystyle |x+2|< 3$ is equivalent to
$\displaystyle -3 < x+2 < 3$ and subtracting two from each

side gives $\displaystyle -5 < x < 1$.

The ratio test also tells us that the series diverges when
$\displaystyle |x+2| > 3$ and this occurs when $\displaystyle x+2 > 3$
or $\displaystyle -(x+2)< 3$.

Isolating for \emph{x} yields $\displaystyle x < -5$ or
$\displaystyle x > 1$.

This leaves only the cases when $\displaystyle |x+2| = 3$, that is, when
$\displaystyle x=-5,1$. To check these, we plug them into the original
series. For $\displaystyle x=-5$ we have

\begin{align*}
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{n(x+2)^n}{3^n(n+5)} &= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{n(-5+2)^n}{3^n(n+5)}\\
&= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{n(-3)^n}{3^n(n+5)}\\
&= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{n(-1)^n 3^n}{3^n(n+5)}\\
&= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{n(-1)^n}{n+5}\end{align*}

Let's look at the limit of the terms. Since as n tends to infinity, we
have that the sequence defined by
$\displaystyle a_n = \frac{n(-1)^n}{n+5}$ has two subsequences that tend
to different values (the even indexed terms limit to 1 since the
numerator is positive and the odd terms limit to -1 since the numerator
is negative). Therefore, the divergence test tells us that the series
diverges when $\displaystyle x = -5$

When $\displaystyle x=1$, we have that

\begin{align*}
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{n(x+2)^n}{3^n(n+5)} &= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{n(1+2)^n}{3^n(n+5)}\\
&= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{n3^n}{3^n(n+5)}\\
&= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{n}{n+5}\end{align*}

Let's look at the limit of the terms. Since as n tends to infinity, we
have that the sequence defined by
$\displaystyle a_n = \frac{n}{n+5} = \frac{1}{1 + \tfrac{5}{n}}$
converges to 1 as \emph{n} tends to infinity. Therefore, the divergence
test tells us that the series diverges when $\displaystyle x = 1$.

Thus the set of x values where this series converges is defined by
$\displaystyle -5 < x < 1$.

This is a second solution for checking the endpoints portion of the
question. After finding the radius of convergence as in Solution 1, this
leaves only the cases when $\displaystyle |x+2| = 3$. To check these
(simultaneously), we check this value in the original series with
absolute values. We have

\begin{align*}
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{n|x+2|^n}{3^n(n+5)} &= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{n3^n}{3^n(n+5)}\\
&= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{n}{n+5}\end{align*}

Let's look at the limit of the terms. Since as n tends to infinity, we
have that the sequence defined by
$\displaystyle a_n = \frac{n}{n+5} = \frac{1}{1 + \tfrac{5}{n}}$
converges to 1 as \emph{n} tends to infinity. This means the summands
$\displaystyle \frac{n(x+2)^n}{3^n(n+5)}$ does not converge to 0 any
time $\displaystyle |x+2| = 3$. Therefore, the divergence test tells us
that the series diverges at the endpoints.

Thus the set of x values where this series converges is defined by
$\displaystyle -5 < x < 1$.
hints: This type of problem always succumbs to the ratio test.

Don't forget to test the endpoints of your interval where the ratio test
is inconclusive!

The endpoints can be shown that when plugged into the series diverge by
the divergence test.
